title: Traveling Salesman Problem & NP-Completeness
description: Test your understanding of TSP, NP-completeness, approximation algorithms, and heuristic approaches.

questions.prompt: What is the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP)?

options.text: Finding the shortest path between two cities
Finding a cycle that visits each city exactly once with minimum total distance
Finding the minimum number of cities to visit
Finding all possible routes between cities

questions.explanation: TSP requires finding a Hamiltonian cycle with minimum total edge weight in a complete graph.

questions.prompt: What is the time complexity of brute force TSP solution?
questions.explanation: Brute force enumerates all (n-1)! possible tours, making it impractical for n > 12.

questions.prompt: TSP is NP-complete, meaning it is both in NP and NP-hard.
questions.explanation: TSP is NP-complete because solutions can be verified in polynomial time, and any NP problem can be reduced to TSP.

questions.prompt: What is the time complexity of the dynamic programming solution for TSP?
questions.explanation: The Held-Karp algorithm uses state compression with O(n² × 2ⁿ) time complexity.

questions.prompt: What approximation guarantee does Christofides algorithm provide for TSP?
questions.explanation: Christofides algorithm provides a 1.5-approximation for metric TSP using minimum spanning trees.

questions.prompt: Which heuristic TSP method starts from a city and repeatedly visits the nearest unvisited city?
questions.explanation: Nearest neighbor heuristic builds a tour by always moving to the closest unvisited city.

questions.prompt: Which problems can be reduced to TSP? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: TSP is NP-hard, so Hamiltonian cycle, vertex cover, and SAT can all be reduced to TSP.

questions.prompt: For what range of cities is dynamic programming practical for TSP?
questions.explanation: Dynamic programming with state compression handles up to 25 cities before becoming computationally expensive.

questions.prompt: Which are real-world applications of TSP? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: TSP has applications in logistics (delivery routes), manufacturing (circuit drilling), and bioinformatics (DNA sequencing).

questions.prompt: If P = NP, then we could solve TSP optimally in polynomial time.
questions.explanation: If P = NP, then all NP-complete problems including TSP would have polynomial-time algorithms.
